title: A Good Match: a Dutch Collocation, Idiom and Pattern Dictionary Combined

author: Carole Tiberius, Information Technology Research Institute, University of Brighton

segmentation: In this talk, I'm going to give you a preview of a new project that we're working on at our Institute.
The project is called what communities word combinations and it will be a new online Fraser logical dictionaries for learners of Dutch as a second language.
And for users of Dutch in general.

This is a Co authored presentation, but unfortunately my colleague let Coleman who is the main driving force behind this project and the main lexicographer working on she can't be here at you relax this week, but she can always be contacted on the email address on the slides.
At the moment the project is still very much in a device design phase, so unfortunately we don't have any data or any application to show you as yet.
But the good news is that we will be able to start production soon after the summer Holidays.
So when talking about word combinations, it's important to define what do we mean by word combinations.
Well, actually very literal.
Any meaningful type of combination of words with spaces so free combinations and multi word expressions like collocations, fixed expressions and idioms.
But more also more abstract, semantically motivated valency patterns and conversational routines.
I will give examples of each of those further along in the presentation.
And this new application is going to fill a gap in the Dutch phraseological landscape, because if we look at this.

Which phrase phraseological landscape today we see that it looks very much like a patchwork of many different resources, each of which focuses either on one or a few type of different multi word expressions.
So we have an idiom dictionary by fan Dollar from 1999.
There is a a collocation dictionary by Pete Decline, but it only focuses on down and Co occurring verbs.
There is the contrast of verb valency.
Dictionary for Dutch.
English and French, which was created in the Contra Graham Project Inherent in 2006.
There are some proverb dictionaries, both old and modern.
We have some lexical databases which contain multi word expressions and probably development is the best known of those.
And a phraseological information is scattered overlay at microstructures in general language dictionaries, as is the case in the alchemy Nails water book TNW.
The contemporary Dictionary of Dutch.
And as we heard already today during the keynote, the focus is tends to be on idioms and less on collocations.
So that's why.
We thought it would be a good match to combine collocations, idioms and patterns in one tool.
And on this slide we give you a.
Impression of what a prototype of our application may look like.
And we will not give access to phraseology and traditional layered microstructure with sensors, but the goal is to offer immediate access to usage patterns.
Um?
By using the toolbar in the middle instead.
They're circle on the toolbar.
There are four options and the options are ordered.
According to their increasing degree of complexity, so we start, you probably may not be able to read it, but completely on the left is example sentences.
Then we get word sketches with collocates.
Then we go to pattern, meaning pairs and finally the last option.
Conversational routines.

So at the moment we are in the middle of a three year pilot, with the phraseology of verbs, and within this pilot will set up the database and will develop a prototype web application and this tool will be a reference tool for language comprehension and language production in Dutch, and the resource will also be able.
Yeah, people also be able to use it for computer assisted language learning and teaching.
So the data can be used by learners, teachers, developers of textbooks, teaching materials and test materials, and the data can also be used by researchers, for instance as a resource for test data.

We will develop a standalone online dictionary application, but the data from our project can also be used in whole or in part in other language learning materials and in other dictionaries, and this is important to mention because actually we started the pilot in cooperation with a small company in the Netherlands which works on remedial teaching software for Dutch and actually their users are the target users of.
Our pilots as well, so they are advanced learners of Dutch in higher education and the rider second language learners or.
Native Dutch speakers who do not have the right level to follow all the courses in higher education.
And the micro structure for the pilot is based on a selection of verbs that was provided by us by the company and in the meantime we have created the pilot corpus based on in-house material.

At the moment the corpus is only tagged and we will start with the tight corpus to go through the to see if we can develop the different options that we want too often and in the second half of this year we're also going to get our corpus passed and then we will run the same experiment with the past corpus because we expect that for Dutch in some instances past corpus will allow us to extract more data automatically than the tagged corpus, and this.
It's especially the case for subjects and objects which are very hard to detect in Dutch, just on the basis of a sequence of tags and for the tools.
While we will use the sketch engine.
With the Good X functionality, the corpus pattern analysis annotation tool and for the dictionary writing system, we very much hope that we could use taxonomy to edit our dictionary data.

So of course we have been inspired by a lot of other projects, some of which are listed on this slide here, and I'm not going to go through all of those here because most of them have already been mentioned.
I just want to mention the string net Navigator, not because it's the most important source of inspiration just because I don't think it has been mentioned yet, and it's.
It's interesting because it's a corpus derived online inventory of 1.6 billion English hybrid engrams, and as it includes hybrid engrams this means that it can be an engram.

Can be any combination of a part of speech, word form and a llama, and by this he creates a large structured net which allows you to investigate degrees of frozen US and variation in multi word expressions.
Let me briefly explain so if you've got the expression.

To keep a close eye on, you can click on I and then you see that you can also fill then watch instead of I and for close that can be replaced by careful for instance and then if you look at the pattern, keep adjective noun on you see that keep is the UN substitutable lexical anchor in this expression.

I've been dealing with patterns.
Well, of course we are inspired by the world by Patrick Hanks and his theory of norms and expectations and the corpus pattern analysis.
An important here is to mention that the pattern is not just a syntactic concept in the theory of norms and exploitations.
A pattern is a form meaning pair in which slots are populated by semantic types.
So for instance, human animal furniture, and these semantic types are labels for lexical sets collocates which can instantiate such semantic type.
So for instance, the semantic type furniture includes.
Lexical items such as table, chair and bed.
Well, so far for the background.
So what do we do?
Aim to develop and I'll talk you through it using the prototype of our demo application as a guideline.
So we will offer four search options.

People can access these usage patterns by looking at examples, sentences, combination possibilities, patterns and conversational routines, and the first option is to show examples of the verb in context.
And we do this similar to the work presented by Robert left earlier.
Research has shown that access to multiple examples of usage is useful to language learners.
This is work, for instance by Anna Frankenberg because good examples sometimes suffice to workout the meaning of the verb and or to get a bird's eye view of its usage patterns.
So even although the user may not realize it here, we have got the sketch engine for language learning with the verb analyze.
The you can see typical objects in these examples, such as analyze objects of analyzer data and results and situation.
You can see that researchers analyze linguists or managers analyze.
You can see that someone analyzes something for a purpose.
Or you can even see a pattern like someone analyzes something as pleasant adjective.
For our project we will.
Do something similar.
Um?

You can type in the verb on that here in Dutch, and then you get example sentences and at the moment we are in the process of fine tuning these examples sentences with the Codex configuration is defining a new good X configuration for Dutch because the one that's used here is based on the configuration that we created for our.
General Dutch dictionary.
So the scholarly dictionary so sentences can be longer.
Not so frequent words well, that's not for me really a problem, But if you're working with language learners.
We expect that we want shorter sentences and we do not want to have very long words and definitely not non frequent words.
The second option will provide the kind of words.
Catch is.
We've also seen them already in this session.
Um?
Yeah, this functionality can support language learners in finding the right collocate to build sentences with the verb, and teachers can use it to decide which collocations they should teach.
In general, the world catches our shoulder llama form.
And overall this is not a problem, but you see one word in red.
I don't know if you can read it, but we've already seen that one of the frequent objects of.
Analyzes data.
And the lemma form of data is there are both in Dutch and in English it seems.

Datum, but in Dutch it's not used form, so people don't talk about the singular of data, so it's in those cases we will post added the word sketches and we will replace the lemma form by the plural form as this noun collocate only occurs in the plural.
Then the user let's zoom in a bit on the relations subject.
We will use grammatical terms, but and I think that in higher education you may expect that students will know what the subject is.
But just in case they don't, we will add a short explanation saying like who analyzes?
And in passive sentences it expressed by by.
And we've learned from non native speakers that in Dutch they like to have quick access to the article that's used with the non collocate.

So whether it's a neuter or non neuter noun, and we think we can do this by adding this article in support superscript before or after the noun, and then when you click on it you get an example sentence.
Which may be post edited if necessary and if doable we will show more example sentences an otherwise maybe a direct linked to concordances in the corpus.
So yeah, word sketches can be very helpful for advanced learners trying to find target collocate quickly or just seeking confirmation of their intuitions regarding a colocation.
But they have one major disadvantage and that is that the collocations are not explicitly linked to a meaning of the verb in context.
And as patterns and meanings often have a preference for a particular set of collocate, which can be grouped in semantic types, this information is essential and has to be encoded.
So that's what we will do in our third option.

This will show collocates that occur in patterns associated with the meaning, and it will support learners in building constructions longer and more complex than the binary combinations provided by the word sketches.
So before I'll show what we want to do, let's have a look at our sources of inspiration.
Here I've got the subpart of.
Analyze in the pattern Dictionary of English the first pattern and then the first pattern of analysieren in the German Valency Dictionary.
And in PDF we see that the patterns have semantic types in the slots.
The collocates that instantiate these semantic types are not given except when they are very restricted.
For example in idioms, and each pattern has an implicature.
That is a definition anchor to the arguments in the pattern and an example sentence is given and has access to more example data.
If the user wants.
Verbs in the German evolvo projects are described in a maximum valency frame, which means that all the elements that are essential to explain the meaning of the verb are encoded as compliments.
And in available you see that these semantic types are embedded in dummies.
So that yes, they call them yay.
Yay meant at first.
So someone something.
So the semantic roles.
This way the semantic roles become more or less implicitly recognizable.
You could say dummies for dummies.
They do have the semantic types and the available dictionary, but you have to know that you have to mouseover the dummy to see them.
And then each dummy in the pattern is also assigned to column and discolored reoccurs in the compliment.
Compliment type names in the construction desserts ball plan and in the lexical items in the examples.
In this way, language learners can easily recognize that complements, even if the word order in the example differs from the pattern.
So what are we going to do well?
What we'll do is fairly similar to what happens in PDF and in Eve album.
We will use the dummies and the color codes from eval, but for the sake of readability and in our project we will introduce a new feature.
We will link the dummies.
But you can see in the middle, next to pattern one we will link the dummies to the collocate that.
Occur in the world sketch and then afterwards we intend to cluster these color case into semantic types.
And this for the semantic types will be aimed to follow the ontology of Patrick hangs.

We do not want to overload the user with information as patterns on your screen can be quite daunting, so we will offer more features on demand, such As for instance, access to the full verb paradigm, information about passivization pragmatics, which elements are optional, etc.
And now you may wonder.
How do idioms and proverbs fit in this?
Well, in fact, idioms and proverbs are patterns with very limited or unique lexical preferences and to specific phrase structures in some or all of the slots.
So we will treat them in more or less the same way as normal patterns, but we will label them so they will be marked as proverb or idiom.
But they will have a pattern as Canonical form.
So instead of saying burying the hatchet, we will get someone buries the hatchet.
And because we do that, we can make semantic types and the lexical sets that can instantiate these variable slots explicit.
And yes, we also would like to have automatic searches for this.
But, and we'll have to see how much we can fit in in our pilot, but the thematic searches are also important for the last.
Option, actually the conversational routines.
Conversational routines like idioms and proverbs are a special type of pattern.
And call MA 1981.

I'm not sure if I pronounce the name correctly, but cool math defines them as highly conventionalized prepatent expressions whose occurrences tide to more or less standardized communication situations.
And these routines come natural to native speakers, but are difficult to master for non native language learners.
And as the pragmatic function of these routines pre dominates over the preferential meaning.
It does not feel right to listen with the semantically motivated pattern meaning pairs.
Moreover, this conversational routines are conventionalized and fixed to the extent that it cannot be produced by language learners.
Simply using the patterns as templates.
You just have to know the conversational routine and therefore it will be better to provide a different access to them.

Stage.

And I want to ask whether you would agree.

That meanings are made up of concatenations of lexical items.

Yes.

Attempts to grapple with meaning.
